Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Medium: Steganography in Empirical Sources Using Acquisition Oracle

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on advancing the field of digital image steganography -- a covert way of communication in which information is hidden in other objects, such as digital media files, to assure privacy. For a secure steganographic system, it should be impossible to prove the presence of hidden data. Achieving this level of security in practice is extraordinarily difficult because digital media is hard to describe using statistical models with accuracy necessary to guarantee perfect security.

This project works with devices that acquire an image to learn a sufficiently accurate model within which it becomes possible to construct steganography with a verifiable level of security and performance that can be contrasted with theoretically achievable limits. The result is a novel advanced privacy tool needed in countries that prohibit the use of encryption or in a hostile environment when there is need to communicate without attracting attention via channels in control of an adversary or via public, insecure channels. On the other hand, a deeper understanding of the limits of covert communication will facilitate better defense against such methods of deception, an effort recognized as steganalysis. The project explores commercial applications of data hiding include signal authentication, integrity verification, and secure data dissemination. This research contributes to trusted information exchange, data mining, information assurance, network and computer security, counter-deception, and intrusion detection and its prevention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Steganography is the ancient art of covert communication in which the actual message being communicated is hidden inside some other, innocuous looking object. Unlike cryptography, which encrypts messages and thus makes the use of crypto obvious, in steganography the very fact that it is being used is non-obvious. Writing with invisible ink or encoding messages in selected letters in a text are examples of techniques used in the past. Modern steganography uses digital media to encode the secrets by, for example, slightly modifying the colors of pixels representing a digital image. With the ubiquitous presence of digital imagery, music, and video, steganography has been experiencing a renaissaince of its own in the past 20 years.

Steganalysis is the counterpart of steganography, an effort to reveal the use of steganography. Most modern steganalysis techniques are based on machine learning or artificial intelligence. Deep convolutional neural networks can be trained on millions of examples of "clean" images and images embedded with secrets to recognize the presence of the slight, invisible changes introduced into a digital image by the steganographer.

Despite the rather explosive development of steganography of recent years, most practical data hiding techniques rely on heuristics. Those few that back their security with solid mathematical arguments are often vulnerable to attacks by artificial intelligence due to the fact that the model used to prove their security is usually overly simplistic.

In this effort, a novel approach to steganography is researched that is capable of resisting even the most sophisticated detectors. The main idea is the realization that the steganographer has one fundamental advantage, which is the device used to prouce the digital media, for example the camera or phone. The steganographer can take many images with their device and better estimate the statistical model of the pixels, which allows them to hide messages more securely. In particular, with the camera in possession, the steganographer can mask the impact of embedding the secret message as the noise inevitably introduced by the imaging sensor. In the extreme case, perfect security can be obtained in both the theoretical sense and practical sense by analyzing the images with the most sophisticated artificial intelligence detectors available today.

Moreover, the principal investigator provided theoretical explanation for why certain heuristic methods work and, based on this insight, managed to further improve their performance. For example, security can be dramatically enhanced when taking more than one image of the same scene and using this "burst" for hiding the message. This method is simple enough that it could be easily implemented for a convenient use in a mobile app.

To solidify the research findings, the principal investigator developed a new generation of steganalysis attacks based on the most recent advancements in deep learning and artificial intelligence as well as novel approaches rooted in purely mathematical arguments. Such constructs are expected to impact the closely related field of digital forensics, and the field of computer security and intrusion detection.

The impact of this research on society is rather wide. Those who work in the field of computer and system security need to be aware of the threats posed by methods of covert communication. This is because malicious code could be smuggled in innocent looking digital media files to facilitate attacks and security breaches. This makes the research related to homeland security, information warfare, and anti-deception. Anti-virus and security constructs, including firewalls, may need to be augmented with algorithms that detect the presence of covert channels to mitigate the risks. Threat detection systems that use data driven systems should include digital media with hidden data during training to be able to detect hidden threats due to covert channels.Steganograhy itself could be implemented on mobile devices for secure covert exchange without relying on strong cryptographic methods, which are illegal in some countries. Some of the novel methods developed during this effort that rely on modest resources could be implemented in mobile apps. Provably secure methods offer privacy in countries that disallow use of encryption and thus facilitate freedom of speech, protect privacy, and offer some level of protection from oppression.
